description.plain:
Chris Stapleton (born April 15, 1978) is a country, bluegrass, and southern rock artist from Lexington, Kentucky. Before his critically acclaimed album “Traveller”, Stapleton wrote songs for the likes of George Strait, Kenny Chesney, Darius Rucker, Adele, Brad Paisley, Dierks Bentley, and Tim McGraw. Stapleton also found success with his band The SteelDrivers, releasing two albums with the band in 2008 and 2010, where he eventually left later in 2010.

Awards/Honors:
Country Music Association Awards:
2015 Male Vocalist of the Year
2015 New Artist of the Year
2015 Album of the Year Traveller
2016 Male Vocalist of the Year
2016 Music Video of the Year Fire Away
2017 Album of the Year From A Room: Volume 1
2017 Male Vocalist of the Year

Academy of Country Music Awards:
2016 Album of the Year Traveller
2016 Male Vocalist of the Year
2016 Song of the Year “Nobody to Blame”
2016 New Male Vocalist of the Year
2016 Songwriter of the Year
2018 Album of the Year From A Room: Volume 1
2018 Male Vocalist of the Year

CMT Music Awards
2016 Breakthrough Video of the Year “Fire Away”

Stapleton has also been awarded with 5 Grammy awards (in 10 nominations), 5 Billboard awards, and 2 iHeartRadio awards, among others. As a composer, Stapleton has received 9 American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP) awards, including the Vanguard Award.

description.plain:
Kentucky songwriter Chris Stapleton’s breakout solo hit is a bluesy ballad about the intoxicating power of love. The song reached #1 on Billboard’s Country Songs chart after Stapleton performed it as a duet with Justin Timberlake at the 2015 CMA Awards.

Ironically (given Stapleton’s notoriety as a songwriter), ”Tennessee Whiskey” is a cover of a country classic—it was a minor hit for David Allan Coe in 1981, and a major hit for George Jones in 1983.

Many have also noted the updated arrangement’s resemblance to Etta James' 1968 R&B classic “I’d Rather Go Blind” (a song Beyoncé covered in the 2008 movie Cadillac Records).

Stapleton recalled the cover’s genesis in an interview with Fader:


It’s always been a favorite song of mine. We had a show in Charlottesville, and we were sound checking, waiting around for the mics to get set up. Me and the guys in the band started playing a little bit and got into that groove, so I started thinking, “Man, what song could I sing over top of this?“ For whatever reason, I started singing “Tennessee Whiskey.”

At the time, we had a steel player by the name of Steve Hinson who used to play with George Jones on the road—maybe that was part of the equation. But we decided to do the song that night and every night since. By the time we got into the studio, it was something we all enjoyed playing. It’s a part of the fabric of things that influenced me over the years.

description.plain:
Either Way is the fifth song on Chris Stapleton’s From A Room: Volume 1 and Stapleton’s own version of the stark ballad he wrote a decade ago. Lee Ann Womack released a version in 2008 that had Stapleton performing back-up vocals. The song is about the indifference of a man in his relationship. Whether it continues or ends, he’s fallen out of love.

The song won a Grammy Award for Best Country Solo Performance at the 2018 Grammys held on Jan. 28, 2018.

description.plain:
“Fire Away” is the second track from Stapleton’s 2015 debut album Traveller. The song was cowritten by Danny Green and Stapleton and produced by Dave Cobb.

The song is about bracing for a heated fight with a particularly sharp-tongued lover and hanging in there no matter what as a form of “loving someone unconditionally,” as Stapleton said in an interview.

See annotations on Verse 2 for a connection of this song to broader relationship themes related to both verbal attacks and partners' natural defense responses.

description.plain:
Broken Halos is the first single that has been released from Stapleton’s From A Room and also the first song on the album.

Chris wrote it with Michael (Mike) Henderson and told Rolling Stone Magazine in an interview why it was important for him to include it on the album:

I wrote that song with my dear friend Mike Henderson, with whom I probably wrote more songs than anyone who is a co-writer of mine. I didn’t include any songs I’d written with him on Traveller, so it was really important to me … to cut songs from some of the guys who helped me learn how to write songs, and Mike is one of those guys.

Broken Halos is a song about people close to us who pass away. At his concert at the Ryman Auditorium in February 2017, Stapleton introduced the song by noting that he wrote it on the day a childhood friend passed away from pancreatic cancer at the age of 37.

The song won a Grammy for Best Country Song at the 2018 Grammys held on Jan. 28, 2018.

description.plain:
“Parachute” is the fourth track from Stapleton ’s 2015 debut album Traveller.

The song is the ruminations of an estranged lover who realizes that the relationship he lost—and now misses—ended because of things he neglected to say or do. He’s willing to come back if she ever reaches a time of need, even if she ignores him until then.

Stapleton performed the song on the January 16, 2016, episode of Saturday Night Live.

description.plain:
With lines like “I fall more in love with you than I’ve ever been,” “More of You” has the lyrical content to risk becoming sap. Its integrity is maintained in Stapleton’s restrained delivery, which makes it more confession than profession.

The likely subject of the song, Stapleton’s wife Morgane, joins in harmony vocals, suggesting all the feelings expressed are mutual.

Contrasts between whiskey and a woman are used to describe the lingering pain of their breakup.

The song was featured on Tim McGraw’s 2007 Let It Go album.

description.plain:
“Nobody to Blame” is a man accepting responsibility (perhaps poorly) for the punishment he’s receiving from the woman kicking him out of their apparently well-established life.

With no reference to exactly what he did wrong, an assessment of the damage focusing solely on his possessions gives listeners the sense that he didn’t appreciate her much, caring more about having good toys than having a good woman.

That irony is deliciously subtle from Stapleton, whose growling baritone make any comedic deliveries exceptionally dry.

description.plain:
The title track from Chris Stapleton’s debut album. Already well known as a songwriter for the biggest music stars, he branches out on his own with a mix of Southern Rock, Americana, country and long-haired soul.

The song uses two senses of the “traveller” label, as Stapleton describes the vagabond life of a musician physically travelling across land, and also frames his lifespan as a parallel trip through time. This latter theme is most apparent in the bridge.



– Chris Stapleton has written over 150 songs and was the lead singer of The Steeldrivers.

description.plain:
Written by Stapleton, Brice Long, and Matt Fleener, “Scarecrow in the Garden” is a spare, ominous ballad about a West Virginia farm that’s been passed down through the family of immigrants from North Ireland.

“Scarecrow in the Garden” is the second song to be released from Stapleton’s new LP, the follow up to From A Room: Volume 1 which was released last May.

description.plain:
This song is about Stapleton’s father. Written while his father was living, Stapleton says the decision to perform it came after his death. He recounts the story that inspired the title and lyrics in an interview with Radio.com:

The concept came when Stapleton went to visit his parents for a holiday. He says his dad was a very religious man who said grace at every meal. One particular time, though, he didn’t, and it struck Stapleton. Soon after, the phrase “Daddy Doesn’t Pray Anymore” was stuck in his head.

“I went back to Nashville and wrote that song and just filed it,” he says. “We pulled it back out for this [album]. It was the right time to do it. Just like everything else, there’s a right time for everything, and it was the time to do that. It wouldn’t have made sense for me to do anything with it in 2005. It wouldn’t have meant as much.”

Source:[http://radio.com/2015/05/08/chris-stapleton-interview-debut-album-traveller]

description.plain: This song details the life of a man struggling, but falling back to find peace and solidarity in the simple pleasures of his life. The depressing sound hides lyrics of an amazing man and how he works through life. He opens by telling us a little about himself,”I work on the factory line”, painting the picture of a low to lower-middle class lifestyle. He goes on the tell us of his struggles in life… his father isn’t doing too good, sister got laid off, high cholesterol, saved up money until his truck broke down. But as he lists all these problems he reverts back to his happiness “the kids and the dogs and you and me”. Like the “sound of a slow simple song” he finds peace and serenity in the happiness he draws from his family. Chris’s voice reenforces the theme of the song. He changes up his typical strong, vibrant, and overpowering delivery and serenades us with these lyrics in a calming and almost depressing tone, only to be lifted in the chorus when he talks about his family. The melody is straightforward yet complicated and somehow upsetting. Through the chorus it picks up, almost to shine through like a ray of sunshine. The beauty in this song is subtle and hard to find, especially when compared to other Stapleton songs, but for those who have found the simple beauty in their life, who have found their “simple song”, this speaks volumes.

description.plain: A man struggling to escape his past. There was a time, before he settled down, when he took advantage of his freedom to party. Hard. But it was a conscious decision and he knew he’d be able to set it all aside when the time came, and assumed everyone would let him. He was wrong on the second point–he’s moved on from that life, but the woman he’s with hasn’t forgotten about it.

description.plain: Stapleton’s first single as a solo artist, released two years before his first album “Traveller”, “What Are You Listening To?” explores the wide range of music and the various moods different songs inspire. Written as a man singing to his ex-lover, Stapleton wonders aloud what song his ex is listening to and, by extension, whether she is carefree, sad, in love, or various other moods.

description.plain: The second song of From A Room: Volume 1. It is a cover of a song originally sang by fellow country artist, Willie Nelson. According to Wikipedia, It was released in October 1982 as the third single from his album Always on My Mind. Nelson’s song reached number two on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart.

description.plain:
As musical numbers in children’s films become more popular, Disney and Pixar take their turn by releasing “The Ballad of the Lonesome Cowboy” for their 2019 animated sequel Toy Story 4 as a single, which is also played during the film’s credits. The song is written by Randy Newman from the perspective of the series' main character Sheriff Woody (voice by Tom Hanks). Newman, who also composed the scores for all of the Toy Story films, told Vents Magazine, “Woody feels like he was a lonesome cowboy until someone comes along and changes his world.”

Newman also shared his excitement to have Chris Stapleton perform the song by simply saying, “Chris Stapleton did a great job on this song” (via Vents Magazine).

Newman, who also composed the scores for all of the Toy Story films, told Vents Magazine, “Woody feels like he was a lonesome cowboy until someone comes along and changes his world.”

Newman also shared his excitement to have Chris Stapleton perform the song by simply saying, “Chris Stapleton did a great job on this song” (via Vents Magazine).
